evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Aside from the stupendous people, company culture, and compensation package,  1. I really appreciated Zebra's approach to promoting the personal learning and development of its team members, and the resources and platform provided as part of the approach (including openness to in-person attendance of events and travel costs - if any). 2. Zebra had great focus on Inclusion and Diversity which was very refreshing. 3. I was also impressed with Zebra's willingness to invest in systems and tools (implementation, maintenance, enhancement/innovation and support) that make the jobs of the employees easier, more productive and more efficient (vs limping along with manual processes and/or rudimentary MS Office-based applications). 4. Promoting innovation was also a strong cultural value.
Cons: 1. While Zebra clearly promoted learning & development and provided opportunities for growth and new experiences at the same general job level, there was no clear career path outlining how to advance, and - for those who target growth into leadership as part of their career journey - there was limited opportunity for advancement.  2. Related to this, when hiring for leadership positions, there seemed to be a strong bias to candidates with work experience in consulting services (i.e., ex-consultants) - most of whom were external candidates. This was very limiting and frustrating to internal candidates who had built strong experience within the company and in whom so much had been invested by Zebra in their professional development (which seemed to be all mis-utilized by the general tendency to continuously hire leaders from the outside).  3. Also, advancement opportunity seemed uneven across different business functions (e.g., new leaders (Directors and above) were being named in IT, HR and Marketing almost every other year - some even jumping from manager to Senior Director within a couple of years vs other areas where senior individual contributors or managers stagnate for many years). 4. Lastly, while also trying to promote innovation, there was an aversion to attempts at relatively significant system- or process changes (even those that had a relatively good business case). The preference was in the general safety of smaller, incremental innovations or improvements.
Advice to Management: Ex-consultants bring great experience, but so do your internal team members in whom you've invested so much. Also, where there may be a reasonable case for such, don't be afraid of making bigger innovations or changes; many times higher risk yields higher return.

Pros: I've worked with some very good employees and direct management. Time off was adjusted a few years ago and is now fairly competitive. Direct managers have been willing to listen to ideas and have encouraged innovation. The merger with the Motorola Enterprise group created a great and synergistic portfolio of products.
Cons: Legacy Zebra employees recently found that not only would they not receive *any* merit bonuses this year, but that the former Motorola employees would receive merit bonuses *and* a profit-sharing type bonus This has de-moralized and de-incentivized many long time employees, who now feel devalued. Meanwhile, management tried to appease employees by saying that their own bonuses were also being "deferred." Deferred simply means "put off until a later time."   This shameful treatment of employees who worked hard to bring Zebra to where it is now is not how you retain your best and brightest talent. And unfortunately with reviews here on this site, it's not how you're going to attract new talent with skills you need.  The backlash from employees actually caused management to rethink their actions, and they came back and offered a whopping 2% bonus as a conciliatory gesture. Unfortunately, that does not sit well with many people. It's perceived as an insult -- a scrap thrown to the dogs to shut them up. I am aware of employees actively looking for new jobs, or considering retirement because of this recent treatment.
Advice to Management: If you want to be Best in Class, then act like it. Treat all employees from all organizations and acquisitions fairly.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Overall good work culture - it's a mature culture. While not vibrant and energized like many tech companies, every one at Zebra overall is kind, supportive and helpful. It is a family friendly culture with good work life balance. Zebra is becoming more open to suggestions and often, although sometimes overkill with too many meetings, they do take the time to ask for feedback and evaluate what can be improved upon. Might be slow to make improvements, but at least employees recommendations are acknowledged and thoughtfully, taken into consideration. For sales, quota is not extreme and overall fair when compared to other sales companies. Although a bit tight-lipped on budget for sales initiatives, they have become more flexible while still being fiscally responsible. Competitive benefits and good sales incentives for top performance. Above all, innovative company with room for improvement but a lot of upside for years to come.
Cons: While behind the curve in being channel friendly for partners, there is still a ton of upside in growing the partner community as Zebra has a highly desirable product line. There is still a big learning curve in how to develop the channel which can make basic industry practices more time consuming due to company's inexperience in having set Channel practices in place. I will give credit that there is effort and open communication in how to improve our program. However; if you really want to accelerate your career in sales at Zebra, which you absolutely can, you will need to be highly self-motivated to learn the breadth of the portfolio and not get stuck on company issues/politics they are in the process of resolving. I think a lot of these cons come from a couple things 1.) they don't recruit enough from the channel; without channel experience they often lose sight in how we can be more competitive and easier for partners to work with because there is no previous experience to be empathetic with the channels needs 2.) they don't tend to hire younger talent - the majority of employees have been in this industry 20-30 years, if they want to continue to accelerate in tech, they need to start opening more opportunities for younger talent to come in, from the channel, to provide fresh perspective.
Advice to Management: Continue to be involved and I challenge you to meet with partners who are not your top 10 to really understand how the partner community engages with competitors and other product lines within the channel. You will not get fresh perspective until you hear from potential prospects what their challenges are; do not be afraid to ask the hard questions. This is not a negative approach, this an approach to take a step in the right direction.

evaluation: Recommends
Pros: Zebra in Vernon Hills provides a fast-paced, interesting work environment for people in electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, technical writing, technical support, or related fields with a plenty of room for advancement into project and product management. There's always a challenge around the next corner, a new problem to solve, or a new product to get to market.  Management has been very good about allowing people time to attend to their personal lives, including working from home whenever that is possible. This flexibility makes it more likely for you to want to work harder and easier for you to put in extra time on those occasions where a project is running full steam ahead toward major deadlines. Good job reviews lead to nice yearly raises. Award and patent plaques line the engineering hallways.  Zebra recently made a more liberal vacation policy that allows people up to 4 weeks off per year, plus a week of sick time per calendar year. The benefits through Blue Cross/Blue Shield are decent, as are the vision and dental benefits. As you could imagine, they would all be better if they were free, but they're still not too bad.  It can be nice to be a big fish in a small pond. Because Zebra is a smaller company, you frequently get chances to work outside of your job description to meet new customer or market demands. Overall, we have great products and incredibly talented people, making this one of the best places to work.
Cons: Zebra is a little top-heavy with upper management, who seems to be making decisions solely to please stock holders, not to keep the best employees. A few managers who have been in engineering forever can be jerks, and they have a relatively high turnover compared to other managers.   Zebra is in the process of moving manufacturing to China, so people in engineering are not 100% sure if they will have jobs in a year or two. That has led to a bit of a decrease in morale in the last year. Management would do well to forget about maximizing profits and to just focus on making the best products on the market.
Advice to Management: Bring manufacturing back to the United States. I used to be proud that our products were made in America. Now I have to worry that they're just made in China junk.

Some of the other benefits are fairly normal, they do offer tuition reimbursement which is nice for those who can take advantage.
Cons: There is not much career growth opportunity. I have no where to go in the company and stay on my current career path, plus Zebra is on a Hiring Freeze. The culture has taken a turn for the worst since acquisition of Motorola Enterprise Solutions. Unfortunately the poor attitudes, poor processes and mediocre upper management were kept from Motorola. There's a reason that company was not doing well, it doesn't make sense why Zebra management has decided to hold on to those reasons. If there is new hires in upper management all were from outside the company - another clue that Zebra is not interested in their own employee career growth. Seems to me that unless you were already in Zebra Management or Pre-Acquisition Motorola you have it good, but not if you were an original individual contributor at Zebra. My sentiments are echoed on the internal site, in social media and right here on glassdoor.com  Also, don't let them fool you...Zebra is NOT a Tech company, they are a manufacturing company who outsource jobs.
Advice to Management: Do not forget who got you to where you are now, some of your employees that are affected by your decisions have been with Zebra 20+ years. Practice what you say your values are and the rest of the company will follow suit. The dissent is reflected in the stock price.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: The interview process was relatively very simple. It consisted of 2 rounds: 1) HR interview  2) Behavioural interview  Both the process was quite smooth. I got the offer letter in less than a month of applying for the position. They have great benefits including multi sport card, food discounts, free coffee. A very flexible work life and they also allow you to do home office.
Cons: My main concern sprouts around how the management deals with their employees. My training consisted of a one hour session on my second day of work followed by throwing tickets and projects along my way when I didn't even understand how the system worked. Also, there is no transparency or open communication between the team manager and subordinates. I was on a temporary contract and I constantly asked if the contract can be extended to my manager to get an idea of where I'm standing. My manager knew from the start that they couldn't extend my contract although I'm progressing and learning quite well and exceeding the KPI expectations due to the fact that the team count is low and they just wanted someone to do the excess load for the time being. I do understand most managers wouldn't want to reveal this to a new employee. However, the problem blew out of proportion when my manager spoke to my colleague explaining he cannot extend my contract but at the same time told me he needs more time to make a decision.  Also, my team members always spoke in czech and didn't speak in English though they could. Hence, I felt left out. I did raise these concerns to my manager who casually said "the guy before you had bigger problems because of language barrier and he was guy and the other team members were girls".  One more tactic that zebra technologies uses is giving you short contracts for 6 months or 9 months. So even if you extend your contract, you are unable to ask for a pay raise. Hence you are stuck in the same position with the same basic salary for the next 2 years. Hence, I decided to search for a new opportunity and resigned before the end of my probation period. Thankfully I found a great opportunity with a higher pay rate in about 2 weeks.
Advice to Management: I'd suggest to hire better team leaders and managers. One of the major issues with the organization is the hiring process should be improved. I have worked in the past with MNCs and had to opportunity to work with amazing managers. Most of the employee complain about the managers in zebra technologies. Always remember that employee retention can be maintained with a good manager and work ethics. People don't leave organizations, they leave their bosses.

evaluation: None
Pros: The company is consverative and usually takes calculated steps to change and improve it's operations. It is financially managed well. You are not pressured to work undue hours and feel good about leaving on time most days. It's a great place to finish out a career if you don't want to try to or have aspirations to move up in the company. As long as you do your job competently you are in a secure position for as long as you want to keep doing your specific role. The IHQ culuture allows you to manage work/life issues reasonably well though not actively making it a policy or promoting it. If you need to work from home you usually can, but you would need to secure your manager approval for regular working hours from home and possibly a re-write of your job description from HR as those are not generally on offer at time of contract.
Cons: If you are looking for career opportunities your only hope is on the Sales side of house. The company has no career development strategies nor earmarked budget to allow you to develop yourself. If you are a budget owner you can add this back in for your own development, of course with the approval of your boss, but don't expect your boss to have any serious talks about how they can help you develop your strengths. The focus is on achieving your smart goals and doing it with less budget year-on-year. As this is a US based company you have to work really hard at mantaining communciation lines with US counterparts as they generally do not keep their promises of keeping you in the communciation loop after you estabilsh you are part of the extended team they need to support. They will send you one communciation and after that return to their old ways of doing things. So, since all of key product managers are in the US this happens all the time across all of the product ranges. It also becomes frustrating when you make suggestions to improve things and since it didn't originate on their homeland they pay little attention to your concerns. It's not until a product gets put on "stop ship" that they begin to try and listen to your suggestions on what needs to be done to keep from loosing the sales pipeline that's currently in place. Also, we continue to be very poor at integrating acquistions. We simply have no proven method of how to do this successfully leading to loads of meetings and paperwork that goes round in circles. Also, we are in the beginning phase of a 3 year roll out of an Oracle ERP system that is to replace 100 separate systems across or global enterprise of companies. This is being run by IT now and they are not engaging the right users early enough in the desgin phases so we know we will be left with further customisation requests after the implementation phase because non-Zebra employees are designing our user interfaces across the work environments. In the meantime, we've are not allowed to fix existing systems that need to align to the changes we've made in our business in general because they would jeopardize the big 3 year ERP rollout of being on-time and on/under budget. This is creating additional manual processes to be undetaken and the senior management won't budge in supporting any investment in minimizing these in the meantime. Thus, morale is now being affected by a lack of concern of the extra work load being asked of certain teams. In the meantime, we've been asked to drive the stock price to double in the next 3 years or $75. So far, after two quarters, we've made only negative headway on this goal. The stock is sitting, at this posting, at $30.99, which is down from it's April 1st Q2 start of $34.53. So, a lot of work to be done yet, plus alot more expense waiting to hit the books as the ERP system launches into rollout phase one in October this year. It appears that after taking prudent measured change approaches in the past, we now are trying to change the business at break-necked speed and that is making it a totally different company to work for now.
Advice to Management: Let's make sure we've got quality products coming out of China the first time from Jabil or get rid of them and move to another company. We are hurting our market position tremendously with rubbish coming out of there that constantly has to be reworked all the time in Heerenveen. Also, we need some clear strategy on what we plan to do (eg. cannabilize) with the Swecoin printer business. We spending way to much time on creating programmes around this family of printers that cost only a few hundred EUROS and the lawsuits that we still haven't cleaned up. I think we need to admit it was a bad acquisition and get out of this game as soon as possible because no one has even put together a technical support plan for future products (no resource assigned) so that we can support it internally let alone externally once it ships. We just look plain stupid trying to answer questions about this product even now. The EMEA product team is reluctant to own it and you can't find one of them who can load the printer and demo it to a customer. All we've done is given each RSM a sales target for each of their people on Kiosks and no training except a product slide set and now we've taken away the only support the Pre-sales guys could have in Staffan so they could learn how the product works and how to demo it to potential partners/customers for sales pipeline buidling. Again, no plan to bring them up to speed to help meet the sales targets set. Are we trying to make bricks without straw here? Lastly, do the partners know we are shooting for $75 stock price yet? Do they know what we are expecting from them in the next 3 years? What are we doing to help them raise our and their games? Please, don't just say focus on verticals. That's just like saying "sell more stuff" in my book. We need strategies that will grow our business above the S & P companies we get bench-marked against and until we do, we won't see our stock price break out of it's funk. Yes, we are a profitable company and that is very important but we are not a highly profitalbe company by a long shot and if we keep making Swecoin type decsiions we'll be even worse.
